Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: What Role Do Glaciers Play in Terrestrial Sub-Arctic Hydrology?
Award.AbstractNarration: This project will develop a comprehensive assessment of the glacier-permafrost-hydrology system in light of anticipated increases in glacier wastage and permafrost degradation with climate warming. Current limited understanding of the integrated effects of glaciers and permafrost on terrestrial hydrology inhibits quantification of the impact of cryospheric changes on arctic water resources. Glaciers in permafrost landscapes feed and recharge aquifers in otherwise semi-arid lowlands, which despite relatively low precipitation rates, contain extensive wetlands. The specific objectives of this study are to 1) assess the hydrologic pathways of glacier wastage within a watershed underlain by discontinuous permafrost through hydrologic and geochemical field measurements, 2) quantify the effect of glaciers and permafrost on recent historical (1960-present) hydrologic fluxes and storage by combining glacier mass balance, hydrologic, and geochemical field measurements with an existing heat- and mass transfer model that couples glacier mass balance to downstream hydrology, and 3) project the future hydrologic regime using custom-derived downscaled climate projections (5 km) for the Tanana River basin, Alaska. The major products of the project will include a quantification of the controls that govern the hydrologic processes in glacier- and permafrost affected watersheds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
To fully make the global simulations useful for accurate assessments of climate change impacts at the regional scale, a high resolution regional climate data is generated by this project. The state-of-the-art mesoscale model WRF (Weather Research and Forecasting) is setup to dynamically downscale one of CMIP5 (Coupled Model Intercomparison Project Phase 5) simulations CCSM4-MOAR (ensemble member MOAR by the Community Climate System Model 4.0) in Alaska, the terrestrial sub-Arctic during the period of 1970-2100.

The downscaled simulations during 1970-2005 are first evaluated with the in-situ observations and persistent biases exist in the downscaled climate. Relatively large cold biases exist in southwest Alaska and the Alaska panhandle, while a slightly warm bias occurs along the west and north Alaska coasts. The downscaled winds are overall stronger than the observed values. While there are far fewer observed precipitation data available in the study domain, the precipitation bias demonstrates that precipitation is overestimated along the Alaska panhandle and underestimated along the south Alaska coast. Biases in the downscaled surface temperatures exhibit strong seasonality. Aside from cold biases in the Alaska panhandle, which occur throughout the year, warm biases along the west and north Alaska coasts occur only during the cold months, while cold biases in southwest Alaska are larger during the warm months. Overall, the downscaled surface temperatures in the study domain are colder than observations, except along the west and north Alaska coasts where warm biases occur during the cold months. The seasonality in wind speed and precipitation biases, on the other hand, is relatively small.

Based on the evaluations against observations, correction methods for precipitation, temperature, relative humility, and wind speed have been developed. Considering the diurnal and seasonal variability, the long-term mean monthly biases are used to correct the downscaled precipitation and the long-term mean monthly hourly biases for the downscaled temperature, relative humility, and wind speed. The corrected downscaled-climate have been used to force the hydrological model WaSiM (Water flow and balance Simulation Model) for hydrological studies in the Jarvis Creek watershed and Eklutna Lake, AK. The downscaled results have been also used to force the Parallel Ice Sheet Model (PISM) for the Juneau Icefield evolution.

Under the RCP6.0 (Representative Concentration Pathways 6.0) scenario, the downscaled climate at 5 km resolution in the Tanana basin, AK, show that by the end of 21st century, summer precipitation will increase over almost the entire basin, while winter precipitation will decrease over many areas of the basin except the southwest of the study area where a relatively great increase will occur. In terms of the extreme temperatures by the end of 21st century, the greatest increase in summer maximum temperature will occur in the southeast part of the study area while winter minimum temperature will increase significantly in the northwest part of the basin. Strong summer daily maximum warming in the southeastern part of study area is due to the reduced snow cover, while strong winter daily minimum warming in the northwest is due to the retreat of Arctic sea ice. For the entire Tanana basin, precipitation, temperatures show clear increasing trends and snow cover will decrease dramatically from current 100 mm to around 50 mm in 2090s.
